Your ValueCollector class is added to the needed class in order to make
public some private or method field in the needed class, isn't it? 

Is it really OK to add this ValueCollector class (and instance) to your
production code for testing purposes? It seems to me a violation of
information hiding. If the value collected was supposed to be exposed you
would have made it accessible. Why isn't this a violation of one of the
basic tenets of object oriented coding?

On Wed, 01 May 2002 11:48:47 -0600 (CST) "J. B. Rainsberger"
<jbr@...> writes:
> Quoting Vladimir Bossicard <vladimir@...>:
> 
> > > I dont think it can replace your print statements
> > > because when you are printing, you are <b> discovering
> > > </b> rather than <b> verifying </b>.
> > 
> > but once you have discovered, you can verify that the class acts 
> the 
> > same way over and over again.  If you keep your print statements, 
> you're
> > 
> > discovering each time your run you tests, which is a lost of 
> time.
> 
> What's more, you may not need your print statements to discover. 
> Here is a 
> common trick I use.
> 
> Suppose I want to debug something by checking a value. I write the 
> smallest 
> test case possible to get to that point. If possible, I write this 
> assertion:
> 
> assertEquals( "", objectInUse.getValueToCheck())
> 
> This will fail and tell me what 'valueToCheck' is, instead. Now I 
> verify by 
> hand and use that as the new expected value.
> 
> assertEquals( "myNewExpectedValue", objectInUse.getValueToCheck())
> 
> If the value to check is buried somewhere, then I need access to it. 
> A 
> collecting parameter will help, at least until I refactor the object 
> under test 
> to be easier to test on its own. With the collecting parameter, I 
> can grab the 
> value at the right moment and assert its value afterwards.
> 
> ValueCollector valueCollector = new ValueCollector();
> ObjectInUse objectInUse = new 
> ObjectInUse(otherConstructorParameters, 
> valueCollector);
> // stimulate objectInUse
> assertEquals( "myExpectedValue", 
> valueCollector.getValue().toString());
> 
> Of course, if I'm forcing myself to do a good job, I work harder at 
> writing the 
> smallest possible test. I learn as much as I can about the objects 
> that 
> ObjectInUse collaborates with. I refactor ObjectInUse to make it 
> easier to fake 
> out its collaborators. Now I can write a really small, fast test.
> 
> etimes, I just put 
> junit.framework.Assert.fail(objectToCheck.toString()) in 
> my production code. It's better than printing a value, because I 
> have the exact 
> stack trace at my fingertips. After checking by hand, I might change 
> it to a 
> useful assertion. I might even leave it in there until I can write a 
> better 
> test. I try not to wait more than ten minutes before writing the 
> test. :)
